title: Gitel Steed
text:
Gitel (Gertrude) Poznanski Steed (May 3, 1914 – September 6, 1977) was an American cultural <a href="anthropologist">anthropologist</a> known for her research in India 1950–52 (and returning in 1970) involving <a href="Ethnology">ethnological</a> work in three villages to study the complex detail of their social structure. She supplemented her research with thousands of ethnological photographs of the individuals and groups studied, the quality of which was recognised by <a href="Edward%20Steichen">Edward Steichen</a>. She experienced chronic illnesses after her return from the field, but nevertheless completed publications and many lectures but did not survive to finish a book "The Human Career in Village India" which was to integrate and unify her many-sided studies of human character formation in the cultural/historical context of India.
Early life.
Gertrude Poznanski was born on May 3, 1914, in <a href="Cleveland">Cleveland</a>, Ohio, the home of her mother, Sarah Auerbach. She was the youngest of sisters Mary and Helen, who both later emigrated to Israel. Her father was Jakob Poznanski, a businessman and Polish native who had come to the United States from Belgium. When Poznanski was still a baby, the family moved to <a href="The%20Bronx">The Bronx</a>, New York, where she was schooled at <a href="Wadleigh%20High%20School%20for%20Girls">Wadleigh High</a>. Though not religious, she adopted the <a href="Yiddish">Yiddish</a> name of Gitel. Her mother was active in the <a href="Women%27s%20suffrage">women's suffrage movement</a> and in leftist politics.
Dr. Steed began a <a href="Bachelor%20of%20Arts">BA</a> in banking and finance at <a href="New%20York%20University">New York University</a>, but embraced the <a href="Greenwich%20Village">Greenwich Village</a> artistic and political life, often singing blues in nightclubs, and dropped out to take a job as a writer with the <a href="Works%20Progress%20Administration">Works Progress Administration</a>. <a href="Raphael%20Soyer">Rafael Soyer</a> painted portrait of her at eighteen, "Girl in a White Blouse", (1932) which is in the collection of the <a href="Metropolitan%20Museum%20of%20Art">Metropolitan Museum of Art</a> in New York City, and she is the medusa-haired subject in Soyer's "Two Girls" 1933 (oil on canvas) at the Smart Museum. In 1933 she met the painter Robert Steed (b.1903), whom she married in 1947.
Introduction to anthropology.
Philosopher <a href="Sidney%20Hook">Sidney Hook</a> persuaded Steed to return to NYU and in 1938 she completed her B.A. with honors in sociology and <a href="anthropology">anthropology</a>, then studied as a graduate at <a href="Columbia%20University">Columbia University</a> until 1940 as a Research Fellow in the Department of Anthropology under Professor <a href="Ruth%20Benedict">Ruth Benedict</a> whom she had met in 1937 and who in 1939 led Gitel Steed's first field experience among the <a href="Blackfoot%20Confederacy">Blackfoot Indians</a> of <a href="Montana">Montana</a>. Benedict's "Patterns of Culture" was published in 1934 and had become standard reading for anthropology courses in American universities for years, and Steed was influenced by Benedict's position in that book that, "A culture, like an individual, is a more or less consistent pattern of thought and action", and that each culture chooses from "the great arc of human potentialities" only a few characteristics which become the leading personality traits of the persons living in that culture. From 1939 to 1941, Steed undertook research for <a href="Vilhjalmur%20Stefansson">Vilhjalmur Stefansson</a>, the explorer and writer on Inuit life then planning a two-volume "Lives of the Hunters", on diet and subsistence; Steed worked on the South American Ona, <a href="Yaghan%20people">Yahgan</a>, and the <a href="Antillean">Antillean</a> Arawak and Carib, and from this formative experience began a dissertation on hunter-gatherer subsistence (not finished until 1969, well after she had established her career).
In 1944, after the <a href="Nazism">Nazi</a> <a href="The%20Holocaust">holocaust</a> against the Jews was exposed, Gitel Steed set aside her anthropology and joined the Jewish Black Book Committee, an organization of the <a href="World%20Jewish%20Congress">World Jewish Congress</a> and other Jewish anti-Fascist groups. With a few peers, she participated during 1944 and 1945 in writing "", an exhaustive indictment of calculated Nazi anti-Jewish war crimes intended for submission to the <a href="United%20Nations%20War%20Crimes%20Commission">United Nations War Crimes Commission</a>. Steed wrote "The Strategy of Decimation" published in 1946 for the Jewish Black Book Committee.
Steed taught at <a href="Hunter%20College">Hunter College</a> in New York 1945 and 1947. While teaching at <a href="Fisk%20University">Fisk University</a> in 1946/1947 she researched the <a href="Negro">Negro</a> in the United States and in Africa and was managing editor of the University's and the American Council on Race Relations' monthly summary of "Race Relations" in America.
In 1947–1949 she joined Dr. <a href="Ruth%20Bunzel">Ruth Bunzel</a> in establishing the China group of Columbia's Research in Contemporary Cultures to study immigrant Chinese culture, primarily in New York City, from 1947 into 1949, working with migrants from the same community from China's <a href="Guangdong">Kwantung</a> Provincial village, <a href="Taishan%2C%20Guangdong">Toi Shan</a>. She undertook life histories, community self-analysis, and projective tests, then proposed an extended field project in the Toi Shan community to understand the interdependency in social and economic relations between migrants and their kinsmen at home. <a href="Margaret%20Mead">Margaret Mead</a> and others joined these Columbia <a href="Cross-cultural%20studies">comparative studies</a> of contemporary cultures and they were incorporated into Mead's "The Study of Cultures at a Distance," 
Steed planned "The Effects of Village Institutions on Personality in South China" and had funds granted for its continuation of her Chinese research in China. However the occurrence of the <a href="Chinese%20Communist%20Revolution">Chinese Revolution</a> of 1948 scuttled the project.
India.
Steadfastly committed to field study of institutional determinants of individual and social character, she took up the suggestion of <a href="psychiatrist">psychiatrist</a>, Abram Kardiner, then associated with Columbia University's Department of Sociology, to pursue a similar study in India. Shortly thereafter, Professor Theodore Abel, Department chairman, appointed Steed Director of a two-year field project of research in contemporary India. Funding was received through a grant from the Department of the Navy. She assembled a research team of Dr. James Silverberg, <a href="Morris%20Carstairs">Dr. Morris Carstairs</a> of <a href="Edinburgh%20University">Edinburgh University</a>, and her husband Robert Steed, leaving for Indian in 1949, where there was added a small staff of Indian workers. They included Bhagvati Masher and Kantilal Mehta, who worked as interpreters; Nandlal Dosajh, a psychologist; N. Prabhudas, an economist who conducted the land use survey; and Jerome D'Souza as cook. In the second year of research, the team also included an Indian assistant, Tahera, as well as Americans Grace Langley and John Koos. Her preparations were aided by her friendship with Gautam Sarabhai, a Gujarati Indian she had met in New York who assisted her in learning <a href="Hindustani%20language">Hindustani</a>. She also trained in the use of a professional camera.
The research goals and procedures were ambitious; to <a href="Empirical%20research">empirically</a> bring together interactions of individual, culture, community and institutions, relating real individuals, not merely statistical patterns, for functional-historical analysis of character formation at the village level in the three settlements chosen: <a href="Bakrana">Bakrana</a>, a <a href="Hindu">Hindu</a> village in <a href="Gujarat">Gujarat</a>; Sujarupa, a Hindu hamlet in <a href="Rajputana">Rajputana</a>; and Adhon, a predominantly <a href="Muslim">Muslim</a> village in the <a href="United%20Provinces%20of%20British%20India">United Provinces</a>. Bakrana was a farming economy in fertile flatlands, exclusively Hindu and with an active <a href="Caste">caste system</a>, largely untouched by the former <a href="British%20Raj">British rule</a> or by land reform changes current then in India. Sujarupa hamlet was a single-caste community in the upland valleys. Adhon was controlled by pro-independence Muslims, with more occupational castes and subgroups than Bakrana, with religious minorities.
Consolidation of ethnographic research in India.
Steed returned to the United States in December 1951 with more than 30,000 pages of handwritten notes and some thousands of ethnological photographs, but infected with <a href="malaria">malaria</a>, and shortly after her return she also developed <a href="Diabetes%20mellitus">diabetes</a> which was particularly difficult to control and frequently put her in hospital. In addition, she suffered for over thirty years from <a href="Pituitary%20gland">pituitary cancer</a>. Illness impaired her later career so that she was unable to receive her <a href="Doctor%20of%20Philosophy">doctorate</a> until 1969, 8 years before her death. In 1963, however, Conrad Arensberg wrote "her reputation and accomplishments are such as to make her lack of a PhD of little moment for her standing in the profession". Her reputation also rests on her unpublished notes; the thousands of pages of interviews, observations, projective test results, life histories, and villagers' paintings, most of which are now in the special collections of the University of Chicago Libraries.
During the eleven years after returning from India and taking up a position at Hofstra College (now <a href="Hofstra%20University">Hofstra University</a>) in 1962 where she continued to her death in 1977, Steed had no university affiliation and promoted her work through seminars and lectures at <a href="Columbia%20University">Columbia University</a>, <a href="University%20of%20Chicago">University of Chicago</a>, and the University of Pennsylvania. In 1953, Steed participated in a Social Science Research Council Conference on Economic Development in Brazil, India, and Japan, analyzing <a href="Morris%20Edward%20Opler">Dr. Morris Opler's</a> "Cultural Aspects of Economic Development in Rural India", then later that year, 1953/4, she analyzed "The Individual, Family, and Community in Village India" in Columbia University's Department of Sociology graduate seminar on the psychodynamics of culture, chaired by <a href="Abram%20Kardiner">Abram Kardiner</a>. In 1954 Steed lectured on "The Child, Family and Community in Rural Gujarat" for the University of Chicago "Seminar on Village India". The lectures and discussions are recorded in the archive. She presented in India symposia at meetings of the <a href="American%20Anthropological%20Association">American Anthropological Association</a>, and the <a href="Social%20Science%20Research%20Council">Social Science Research Council</a>.
Her one publication of note during this period was a chapter "Notes on an Approach to a Study of Personality Formation in a Hindu Village in Gujarat", illustrating cultural and institutional influences on the personality of a single <a href="Rajput">Rajput</a> landowner, for a volume "Village India: studies in the little community" edited by Alan Beals and Dr. McKim Marriott, published in 1955; Steed's chapter has been held up as a model for the treatment of personality problems and culture in India. This, and the presentations she made at conferences assisted her in delimiting her doctoral thesis "Caste and Kinship in Rural Gujarat: The Social Use of Space".
During these eleven years she gave birth to her son, Andrew Hart (b. 1953), and taught English at the <a href="Jefferson%20Schools">Jefferson School</a>, a Manhattan private school favored by the political left. Gitel and husband Robert Steed opened the doors of their house on West 23rd Street to visitors who included Ruth Bunzel, <a href="Sula%20Benet">Sula Benet</a>, <a href="Vera%20Rubin">Vera Rubin</a>, <a href="Stanley%20Diamond">Stanley Diamond</a>, <a href="Alexander%20Lesser">Alexander Lesser</a>, <a href="Margaret%20Mead">Margaret Mead</a>, and Conrad Arensberg.
In 1970 Steed revisited <a href="Bakrana">Bakrana</a>, its population then doubled since her last visit, to observe the impact of the transforming politics in India.
Photographer.
<a href="Edward%20Steichen">Edward Steichen</a>, Director of the Department of Photography of the Museum of Modern Art, said Steed's photographs of Indian villagers, which though taken for the anthropological record and used as illustrations in varied lectures and presentations, ranked "with first-rate human interpretations by professional photographers." In 1953, Steichen mounted "Always the Young Strangers" exhibition at <a href="Museum%20of%20Modern%20Art">MoMA</a> in honour of <a href="Carl%20Sandburg">Carl Sandberg's</a> 75th birthday and included Gitel Steed's photos, six of which are in the Museum's permanent photographic collection. Steichen again used her pictures in the Museum's world-touring blockbuster, <a href="The%20Family%20of%20Man">The Family of Man</a> exhibition and book. Her photographs were republished in the <a href="The%20New%20York%20Times">New York Times</a>, and featured in the <a href="St.%20Louis%20Post-Dispatch">St. Louis Post Despatch</a>. While at Hofstra University, her photographic work was exhibited as part of the University's "Focus on India" presentation in 1962, and in 1963 Hofstra showed Steed photographs of Hindu and Muslim villagers. That same year Steed held the exhibition "Child Life in Village India" at the New Canaan Art Association Gallery in Connecticut and another, "Cradle to Grave in Village India" at the Hudson Guild Gallery in New York. In 1967 Vincent Fresno's "Human Actions in Four Societies" used a selection as illustrations.
Death and legacy.
Dr. Gitel Steed died in the night of September 6, 1977, evidently from a heart attack, at the age of sixty-three. She was survived by her husband and supporter for thirty years, artist Robert Steed, and by her son, Andrew.
The Gitel P. Steed papers 1907–1980 are archived in the University of Chicago Library and extend to approximately 13 linear metres (43 feet) of material. Most is data from her Columbia University Research in Contemporary India Field Project of 1949–1951 collected from three villages in western and northern India; extensive life histories of informants, psychological tests, typed notes, field notebooks, photographs, genealogies, histories, transcripts of interviews, and art work, mostly watercolours, by both researchers and child and adult villagers. These are joined by records of lectures and other publications relating to the India Project by Steed and by other scholars. Also held is data from Steed's previous fieldwork project among Chinese immigrants in New York City. The collection was given to the University of Chicago Committee on Southern Asian Studies by Robert Steed in 1978 and conveyed to the University of Chicago Library in 1984. Prior to their arrival, James Silverberg and McKim Marriott put the papers a preliminary order reflected in the collection's current organization. The collection was augmented by Robert Steed in 1985 and 1989, and by McKim Marriott and James Silverberg in 1994. <a href="https%3A//www.lib.uchicago.edu/e/su/southasia/steed.html"></a>
